YouTube user Elman511 cracked open an over-sized egg that was laid by one of his hens. He found a standard-sized egg inside, along with yolk and white. The unusual occurrence is down to a counter-peristalsis contraction. This is when a second oocyte is released by the hen's ovary before the first egg has completely traveled through the oviduct. This causes the second oocyte to travel down the oviduct and is covered in a shell, creating a giant egg around the first one.

Eshima Ohashi bridge in Japan is the third largest of its kind in the world. It spans a mile across Lake Nakaumi, linking the cities of Matsue and Sakaiminato. The two-lane concrete road bridge stretches 1.7km or just over 1 mile long. Its incredible slope, which has a gradient of 6.1 per cent on the Shimane Prefecture side and 5.1 per cent on the Tottori Prefecture side, gives it a rollercoaster-like appearance.

Automated Planet Finder (APF) is a 2.4-metre automated telescope. It consists of a 2.4-metre automated telescope and a high-resolution spectrograph. It splits starlight into a rainbow of colours, splitting it into a spectrum of thousands of different wavelengths. The robot observes nearby stars for months, in search of rocky planets.

Named Hyperion is one of Saturn's outer moons, measuring 255 by 161 miles (410 by 260km) The moon's porous surface can be seen in incredible detail in this image taken by Cassini. It's odd appearance is attributed to its low density for its size. This means it is composed of water ice with only a small amount of rock.

The USA Freedom Act would allow the NSA to request certain records held by the telephone companies under a court order. The authority to collect those records and other related surveillance provisions of the Patriot Act. The bill would result in phone companies, not the NSA, collecting so-called'metadata' on trillions of phone calls. The bill faces an uncertain future in the Senate, where Mitch McConnell is sponsoring his own bill to extend the PATRIOT Act until 2020.

Fossils from an extinct pygmy sperm whale that died seven million years ago. They indicate that the organ involved in sound generation and echolocation got smaller throughout the whale's evolution. US researchers claim that exact prices of goods on eBay attract higher offers than round numbers. Items with precise prices attract higher offers than those with round numbers. Astronomers have used a telescope in New Mexico to watch a star take shape over eight years. The images were taken by the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array in New Mexico. The first image shows the star as seen in 1996 with its dust wrapped around it. The second image was taken by an international team of astronomers last year. They show the outflow of material from the star has dramatically expanded. The dramatic changes are giving an unprecedented look at how young 'protostars' develop into fully-fledged stars.

Scientists at the University of Connecticut say we know how far away the source of a sound is by listening to the echoes it produces. They found that the reverberations of sound helps us locate the distance of a car passing round a bend or a person nearby. The research was conducted by scientists from the University of Connecticut and published in the Journal of Neuroscience. They said that echoes and fluctuations in volume are the cues we use to figure out the distance between us and the source of a noise.

The Sokaze-ki Q uses fluid dynamics to take air in at the rear of the device. It then moves it through specially designed channels to move it to the front. This airflow pulls in additional air from air inlets plotted around the Q. This airflow is then released through the main outlet. The Q is on sale in Japan for 39,350 (£220) and is available in Crystal Red, Champagne Gold and Pearl Pearl White.

Scientists funded by Cancer Research UK studied samples taken from tumours in the prostate and around the body. DNA revealed details of how the cancer metastasises, or spreads. It seems that most of the cells in a tumour stay where they are, but a small number have the ability to travel through the body. These cells are the ‘root’ of the cancer and for a treatment to work, they should be destroyed.

Greenstone is a small egg-shaped device that acts like a beacon, or a beacon. It helps messages move around so-called wireless mesh networks more easily. It was created by developers at Open Garden and uses the FireChat app. It uses Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) that was introduced in iOS 7. It creates a wireless mesh network that connects phones to each other. This means messages can be sent to people in close proximity. But there are limits to how far a message can travel in this way.

One-Touch-911 app was designed by researchers at Boston-based MIT. It works with emergency dispatchers in 135 countries. Each of the four buttons trigger a standard call to dispatchers. Each call is placed with the phone's GPS location, user details and any pre-entered medical information attached. If the user doesn't have signal on their network, the app lets them 'roam' onto another network to connect the call.

Researchers in Tokyo, noted that rats flatten their ears and narrow their eyes when they are in pain. They also puff up their cheeks when they are in pain. To test the rodents' response to rats' pained expressions, they showed them the photos in a specially made cage. They found that rats spent less time in the room showing rodents in pain than they did in the other compartment showing rats with neutral expressions.

Research on infants' brains by doctors from Oxford University has found that young babies are more sensitive to pain than adults. It overturns the medical consensus that newborns have a high pain pain threshold. Until now doctors have assumed that the brains of young babies are not developed enough to feel pain. But the new findings suggest that not only do babies feel pain, but their pain thresholds are even lower than those of adults.

The remains of a prehistoric woman were discovered in the El Mirón cave in Cantabria, Spain. Researchers found spores of several mushroom species embedded in the plaque. The spores were from grilled fungi and bolete fungi, which are thought to have been eaten by early humans. The study provides the oldest evidence yet that mushrooms were eaten by early humans.

Shoe that Grows has adjustable points at the front, sides and the back of the sandal to help it expand. Kenton Lee, from Nampa, Idaho, came up with the idea while working in Nairobi, Kenya. He saw children running around barefoot and in shoes several sizes too small. Pressure sensors in the shoe tells it when your foot is in position, triggering a tiny motor in the heel. When you want to take off the shoes, click your heels together twice and the motor will loosen the laces.

The photos were shot by Linden Gledhill from Staffordshire, who combines his love of photography and a PhD in biochemistry. The 51-year-old uses a modified microscope and camera to capture the detail of the butterfly's wing pattern. Butterfly wings are covered by thousands of microscopic scales split into two to three layers. Each scales is pigmented with melanins that give butterflies black and brown colouring.

Kaylie Milliken is the filmmaker behind Billion Dollar Bully, a documentary that will expose Yelp's shady advertising practices. Yelp, founded in 2004 by two former PayPal employees, is a website that lets users write their own reviews of businesses like restaurants and doctor's offices. The company's revenue comes mainly from advertising and the businesses that buy ads are often rated and reviewed on the site. Yelp has vigorously denied the claims, but Milliken says she's already interviewed several small businesses who say they's been targeted

The '#kyliejennerchallenge' is sweeping social media, encouraging teens to blow their lips up to epic proportions. Participants place their mouth over the opening of a cup, jar or shot glass and sucking in until the air vacuum causes their lips to swell up. Countless teens, both boys and girls, have been sharing their results on Twitter and Instagram. The method works by way of the airlock created in the opening of the glass or jar.

Patients wait an average of 14 days for a decision, compared to 29 days for those diagnosed via more conventional methods. The USS Oklahoma capsized after being hit by nine torpedoes during the December 7, 1941, Japanese forces' surprise attack on Pearl Harbor. Altogether, 429 sailors and Marines onboard were killed, but only 35 were identified in the years immediately after. Hundreds were buried as unknowns at cemeteries in Hawaii, and in 1950, they were reburied as unknowns in Honolulu's National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific.

The Royal Australian Mint has released a new $2 coin to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the landing of Anzac troops at Gallipoli. The coin has an image of poppies among crosses similar to those that mark the graves of fallen soldiers. It also features a small circle that is the colour of red poppy flowers. The coin will be in circulation from Monday, but an artist's impression of the coin clearly shows the craftsmanship involved.

Spanish researchers say climate change impacted human migration. Until 1.4 million years ago it was too cold to inhabit southeast Spain. But then the climate warmed to 13°C (55°F) and became more humid. This enabled hominins - our distant ancestors. - to move to new regions. And it is thought that the earliest humans were a'slow-moving' species.

The study was conducted by scientists at Purdue University in Indiana. They were investigating how to reduce bird to aircraft collisions by keeping birds away from planes. Research showed that birds responded most to blue lights on planes. But when the lights were on, their response slowed. And they only became more alert when the lights were turned on. This could help to capture birds' attention before an aircraft takes off.

Scientists at Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School have developed a device that clips onto the smartphone. When binds to cancerous cells, the beads change the way light passes through them. When clumped around a cell, the beads produce distinctive diffraction patterns. The results can be sent to a central computer for analysis. The device can asses 100,000 cells from a single image in around 45 minutes.

Deep water gas hydrates in the Arctic are reservoirs for abiotic methane. The gas forms through a process called serpentinisation. It occurs when seawater reacts with hot mantle rocks exhumed along large faults within the seafloor. The reservoirs are secure, and scientists don't believe they will impact climate change. Instead, they say similar formations could someday be used to store methane.

Security researchers have found a way to intercept a person's fingerprints. The flaw lies in older versions of the Android operating system. Once a hacker has access to the kernel, they can monitor data sent to and from the phone. When a fingerprint is scanned it is encrypted and stored in a secure folder. But the flaw allows them to collect scans from the fingerprint sensor before it becomes encrypted.

Facebook has launched a new app called Hello designed to give you more control over who can call you. It pulls in any publicly-shared data from a user's Facebook profile. When a user receives a call, Hello shows them info about who’s calling, even if they don't have that number saved. It also lets users block unwanted calls and search for people and places. The free app is currently in testing and is only available on Android devices in the US.

Identical twins share 100 per cent of their genes, but it's impossible to tell which sibling a sample comes from. Identical twins start life with the same genes because they come from the same fertilised egg. But as they age age different life experiences create variations in the number of hydrogen bonds in the DNA. Scientists in Colorado have found evidence for a new solar season season. Every two years it appears 'bands' of magnetic field move to the surface. This combines with the existing 11-year solar cycle, causing even more powerful coronal mass ejections. The changes are caused by twisted, ring-shaped 'bands' of magnetic fields. These 'bands' are 'waves' that can expand and warps the sun's activity.

The Grimes Cottage is one of the oldest surviving homes in Sydney's harbourside suburb of Millers Point. The home was built by whaling captain George Grimes who constructed a row of early 1840s terraces depicted in artist Conrad Marten's work in 1843. The 416sqm inner city block property has a large northerly garden with footsteps down to the heart of the historic area of The Rocks. The property has a formal lounge and dining room with original fireplaces, high ceilings and an open-plan kitchen

The fossil is being sold by Hong Kong-based experts Evolved. It is more than 95 per cent complete bone, is 9.2ft (2.8 metres) long, 5.2ft (1.6 metres) high and 4.6ft (1.4 metres) wide. It belonged to a male Triceratops that lived 66 million years ago. WWF identified 11 'deforestation fronts' where 80 per cent of projected global forest losses by 2030. The areas are the Amazon, the Atlantic Forest and Gran Chaco, the Choco-Darien, the Congo Basin, East Africa, eastern Australia. The fronts are home to indigenous communities and endangered species such as orangutans and tigers.

The Nanoheat Wireless Heated Mug is fitted with a rchargeable battery, nanoheater and heat sleeve. It can maintain temperature of hot drinks at between 68°C and 71°C (155 and 160°F) for up to 45 minutes. The mug weighs a little over one pound (454g) and can be charged wirelessly or using a traditional USB cord.
